title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
(Note: I am reviewing Civilization 6 with all of the expansions and the New Frontier Pass in mind)

It's a really fun Civilization game to play when you want to switch it up, but it's not quite as good as Civilization 5. If it had these main things then I would consider this my go to Civ game:

1. A better world congress. Civ 5's world congress was PERFECT and besides the fact that the AI loved to ban luxuries for no real reason, it was great. It allowed for trade embargoes, world ideologies / religions, and other sanction-like resolutions to be passed. Civ 6's world congress acts as a competition for temporary bonuses rather than a true international council. The worst resolution in Civ 6 has to be the one that removes a player's nuclear stockpile if passed. This is like if the UN voted for the complete disarmament of the United State's nuclear arsenal and the next day it completely disappeared. Not realistic at all! Also, I do miss how the world congress was created in Civ 5, where it was only founded when someone discovered all of the civilizations in the world. I don't like the idea of having a world congress session and not knowing who the other players participating in the votes are.

2. It needs a better ideology system similar to Civ 5. The moment when you get to pick an ideology in Civ 5 is always fun. Whether it's fascism, communism, or democracy, being able to influence another Civilization's government to flip to your ideology is one of the best parts of Civ 5. This can create Cold War like scenarios between the superpowers of the atomic era. Seeing my friend's empires on multiplayer hanging on by a thread as they try to keep their ideology alive despite their large of amount of dissidents, only to end up flipping to join mine is one of the most satisfying experiences ever. In Civ 6, you pick an ideology and you don't really face any consequences besides being disliked by leaders with different forms of government. Having tourism being used for more than just a victory condition is a must have!

3. Finally the AI. In my honest opinion, I think it's worse in Civ 6. No matter the difficulty, the AI always seems to be lackluster. When it comes to war, the AI doesn't know how to properly make use of their air power. I usually NEVER see the AI using bombers or fighters in Civ 6, where in Civ 5 the AI did use them almost always (even to intercept my bombers using their fighters). They also don't even know how to properly use support units, I never have scenarios where the AI attacks my city with siege towers or takes advantage of anti aircraft guns. Another issue with the AI is how unbalanced they are even though they're all on the same difficulty. I would often see majority of the AIs in the Renaissance / Industrial era with one or two AIs in the atomic / information era. This sort of ruins the immersion because it's very unrealistic to see nuclear capable Civilizations with modern infantry fighting against Civilizations with cannons and musketmen. In Civ 5, you may see this at times but usually majority of the AI doesn't stray too far off from the top players. The ones who are behind technologically are usually there because they suffered huge losses in a war. This could probably be fixed if the AIs had better and more balanced spawning areas where they can all equally take advantage of adjacency bonuses and available resources.

Ultimately, I do recommend Civ 6 if you're an established fan of the series. It's still really fun as long as you don't directly compare it to Civ 5 and view it more as its own game. Though if you're a new player to the Civilization series I highly recommend playing Civ 5 first before trying this one out, you'll see what I mean.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
Long time Civ player. I've played every version and knockoff. Extensively modded Civ 2, built scenarios for the public, created art, etc. I have not played nor intend to play the latest Civ 6 DLCs even though I did buy the base game early to get the initial free nations. 

Would I recommend the game? Sure, it's Civ. It's a playable game that allows some historical fantasy to creep in. The graphics are beautiful. Would I recommend spending more than $40 on it, with ALL the DLC's included? No. Spend your money on some indie studio game that offers more depth and way better gameplay. 

The Bad: 

1. Poor AI (which is no surprise from past games) AI units get lost, move around habitually from point A to B and back again. Wars are won based on attrition, production, and tech advantages- not clever strategy. 

2. Poor optimization in late game causing AI turns to take minutes. Just no. It's 2020. 

3. Small maps compared to previous games. The game becomes unstable with large maps, exacerbated by the poor optimization. 

4. Form over substance. They prioritized graphics over gameplay. This is less a strategy game and more so a pretty Settlers of Catan. More so a board game and less so grand strategy. It's obvious they aimed for tablet players.

The Good:

1. No other game does Civ better than Sid Meier's Civ. Until there comes a City Skylines for their SimCity, Firaxis can just keep churning out eye candy and overcharging for DLC.

2. It's fun to pretend you're leading a famous nation, but there's always some immersion breaking issue with Civ 6 that causes me to drop it for a year.

3. It's pretty. Gorgeous really.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
I'm an old and have been playing Civ since Civ1 since it was first released in 1991.  Civ1 is still my all time favorite game.  All the other Civ versions through Civ5 were just Civ1 embellished with bells and whistles.  Civ6 has significant changes and while it plays a bit like Civ1, it does feel fairly different.  The differences among the civilizations can be substantial and even game altering.

But the game is a bit tedious and there is zero chance that while playing I will look up at the time to find out that it is 3:30 AM.  

Overall, I like the game, but it is a long way from Civ1 on my list of all time favorite games.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review: This was my first full experience in the Sid Meier's Civilization series. Coming into it, I had seen mixed reviews, mostly people saying that 5 was better. However, having played this for a while now, and with the two large expansions and now the New Frontier Season Pass, the game just keeps getting better and better! IF you avoided this because of people just wanting to play 5 again, ignore them. This game is outstanding and they keep making it better to keep the fans happy.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
If this is your first Civ game or you play casually then the game is great, otherwise it'll be hard to feel like you're getting your money's worth.
There are really fun things about the game but they're all overshadowed by the lack of polish.

[Pros]
-Runs well on weaker PCs
-City placement is really fun once you get used to the District system. Intersecting multiple city's districts to buff each other, utilising the map's environment effects; This is 6's main strength
-A lot quality-of-life additions from 5

[Cons]
-The various mechanics they've added overtime haven't been refined. It almost feels like a Frankenstein of systems.
-The AI is bad, including when compared to other games. The problem stems from them not understanding the game's systems, even the basic ones. Usually this is something modders fix but Firaxis limits modding for 6 so the community can't fix it.


I'd say 6 is better than un-modded Civ 5 but modded 5 (like Vox Populi) blows this away.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
Civ 6 is a great game, but I am only hesitantly recommending it. The reason is because of all the dlcs. I am of the opinion that dlcs are meant to add side content, and should not just be paid updates. The dlc for civ 6 includes a lot of features that should probably just be included in the base game. I understand the developers might need money, but in that case would it not be better to raise the price of the base game then to sell it incomplete? As someone who cannot afford the dlc, it is very frustrating when everyone else has a better version than you, making it hard to play multiplayer and find videos about the base game only.

Which brings me on to the next point, which is that this game's tutorial is pretty bad. While it teaches you some of the fundamental mechanics, there are TONS of features that arent told anywhere in the game. Combine that with most people playing the dlc version and it makes it extremely rough to learn all the little rules of the base game, which is something you need to know to play any strategy game seriously. The game has an in-game guidebook called the Civilopedia, but it is a nightmare to find what you are looking for and some things arent in it at all.

All that being said, if you can get past these hurdles this is a really great game. The strategy goes pretty deep and the different civilization benefits combined with the randomness of the map can make each game feel unique. There are also smaller updates that happen to the base game over time to improve it that don't cost any money. I've sunk a lot of time into this game and I'll probably sink a lot more.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
An amazingly solid entry into the Civ series. While Civ 5 may have better strategical gameplay this Civ runs like a charm and is really good with the fairly decent modding community. Tons of fun in a fairly deep but easy to grasp turn based strategy game. I have so many memories playing this game after school, staying up late because I need to finish the next turn, this game just has such a close place in my heart and is a really brilliant chill strategy game to play with friends or alone. 

8/10

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
It's good, I guess?
If you haven't played a Civ game and enjoy complex, tactical games with multiple paths to victory, stop reading and just buy this right now.

But at the same time, I've grown weary of the franchise. Maybe it's because the AI cheating feels more noticable in this one, or once I hit a certain Turn #, I know I'm going to win in x amount of turns, so I just lose interest.

It's gorgeous and wonderfully complex and I've clearly gotten my money's worth, but Civ has yet to re-capture the charm of Civ 2 and Civ 4 for me. Maybe lightning only strikes twice.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review:
Its a must buy for those who like previous civilization, strategy games or even for some one who wants to try out this game as a new genre but if you are completely new then it will take some time to understand all the game mechanics and concepts before you can really start enjoying the game so learning curve is something you might want to keep in mind. (the curve is not as bad as paradox grand strategy games)

My first civilization game was civilization V which I played for many hours and I thoroughly enjoyed playing that game, coming over to Civilization VI quite a bit late after its release but I must say my timing feels right because I have played the game with Rise & Fall and Gathering Storm DLC's and I feel without the DLC's the game isn't  as much fun so buying the game with all DLC's seems perfect to me, btw I am a huge fan of natural disasters.

 I rate this game 10/10 great job improving on civilization 5 which already was an awesome game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review: Civ 6 is a game about patience and planning in order to succesfully build your civilization. Small choices in the early game can lead to big impacts later on such as whether to build a wonder now or have it possibly taken by another civ or whether to build a specific building and having your science or culture begin to ramp up. 400 hours in and i still feel like i have more to learn about the game.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review: Mechanically its a step up from previous games, but having played 100 hours here, and over 2500 hours in Civ V, it is a major step down in performance, fraught with instability in an attempt to provide novelty when none was needed. Modding is somewhat easier, but overall the UI is a monstrosity compared to the simplicity of V. I love the game and the series, but I can't recommend it.

my sibling has terrible spawning luck, though; they almost always start on a tundra tile. Great, if you're Canada; misery for anyone else.

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review: If you have played the Civ series before, then you can expect a continuation of the familiar experience, except slightly better in many ways. If you havent played any Civ games, then this is as good as any to start - and start you must!

title: Sid Meier's Civilization® V
review: Really fun strategy game but tbh I like it most just to play as and against some of the most badass people who ever lived. Plus you kinda learn a bit about people and cultures that your school probably overlooked while they were talking about the war of 1812. One problem I do have with the game is that I really want to be able to finish a game in one sitting but it kinda feels impossible to do that. I really often get bored of the game after spending four hours on it and just end up starting a new one later. (I tried adjusting the speed of the game but I haven't found that it helped much).
